category.name: Environment property
category.entry:
If an environment does not contain a literal problem description, the programs implicitly induce problem descriptions of the form [0;P] for each program P.

The environment property ProofObligation.termination can be used to specify whether these problems should include a termination proof obligation (total correctness; using modality [[·]]) or should not consider termination (partial correctness; using modality [·].

Set it to "true" for total correctness, "false" for partial correctness.

The environment property CompoundStrategy.strategies can be used to specifify the automatic strategies which are to be bundled to conduct an automatic proof. The order in which they are specified gives their order of application.

Usually the default is a good value. If you want to deviate, specify a comma separated list of implementing classes. If no package is given, "de.uka.iti.pseudo.auto.strategy." is assumed.

Example: 

 properties
   CompoundStrategy.strategies
      "HintStrategy, SimplificationStrategy, BreakpointStrategy, SMTStrategy"

TODO SimplificationStrategy.splitMode

SPLIT; DONT_SPLIT; SPLIT_NO_PROGRAMS SplitMode lists all possibilities to handle splitting:

  1. Do it whenever a splitting rule application is found
  2. Never do it
  3. Do it only if no program terms are anywhere on the sequent (symbolic execution first)
Use the property order.fct to specify the order ... TODO IVILDOC
The environment property BreakpointStrategy.stopAtSkip can be used to specify whether symbolic execution should stop whenever reaching a skip statement. The value can be "true" or " false".

The environment property BreakpointStrategy.obeySourceBreakpoints can be used to specify whether symbolic execution breakpoints set on level of the source code program are to be enabled. The value can be "true" or " false".

The environment property BreakpointStrategy.stopAtSkip can be used to specify whether symbolic execution should stop whenever reaching a goto statement of which one target lies before the current location. This happens usually only at the end of a loop. The value can be " true" or " false".

The environment property BreakpointStrategy.obeyProgramBreakpoints can be used to specify whether symbolic execution breakpoints set on level of the ivil program are to be enabled. The value can be "true" or " false".

category.name: Rule tag
category.entry:
Rule tag rewrite

"rewrite" expects a string argument.

It declares the set of rewrite rules to which a rule belongs. They list of known rule sets include the following:

  1. "updSimpl" - update simplification
  2. "close" - rules to close goals
  3. "concrete" - rules involving operations on constants ( false | a to a)
  4. "prop simp" - propositional simplification
  5. "fol simp" - first order simplification
Rule sets are applied in that order by the simplification strategy. There are other rule sets for more specific purposes. "symbex" is used for symbolic execution for instance.

Rule tag autoonly

"autoonly" does not take an argument.

It makes a rule invisible for manual application.

Rule tag decisionProcedure

"decisionProcedure" expects a classname as argument.

It denotes the decision procedure plugin to instantiate.

Rule tag additionalParam

"additionalParam" expects a string as argument.

The format of the string depends on the DP to be used. It is given to the DP on the command line.

Rule tag hintsOnBranches

"hintsOnBranches" takes a comma separated list of integer numbers as argument. It is used by the proof hint strategy to decide on which child branches hints are to be applied. The first child branch has number "0".

Rule tag asAxiom

"asAxiom" does not take an argument.

It marks a rule to be translated into an axiom which allows it to be translated to SMT. This is not possible for all rules.

Rule tag derived

"derived" does not an need argument.

It marks a rule to be inferrable by the rules preceeding it (plus includes)

Rule tag display

"display" expects a string as argument, possibly with embedded schema variables.

This string is used to annotate history entries and proof tree component labels.

The format is the following:
Text Replacement
{%c} The text representation of the instantiation for the schema variable, "??" if not instantiated.
{explain %c} The text representation of the annotation statement to which %c points (if it does exists). Empty string otherwise.
{explainOrQuote %c} The text representation of the annotation statement to which %c points (if it does). The statement otherwise. Empty string if %c does not hold a program term.
{property name} The value of the named property of the rule application.
{upd U} The textual representation of the value of the instantiation of the schema update.

Rule tag fromRule

"fromRule" takes a rule name as argument.

It is added automatically to axioms which are generated automatically from rules. The argument is set to the name of the originating rule.

"prio" expects an integer as argument.

Rule tag prio

When sorting rules, the priority is used as comparison criterion.

Priorities have to be between 100 and 999, where higher priority means the rule is likelier to be applied.

Rule tag timeout

"timeout" expects an integer as argument.

For decision procedure rules. The time to wait before shutting down the DP.

Rule tag verbosity

"verbosity" expects an integer as argument.

It defines from which verbosity level on the rule is printed in the proof component.

category.name: Plugin Configuration
category.entry:
Configurating the Plugin Manager

Meta function
Meta functions are functions which are translated to terms during rule application. The instances of class de.uka.iti.pseudo.environment.MetaFunction are registered under the key metaFunction.
Where condition
Where conditions decide when rules are applicable. The instances of class de.uka.iti.pseudo.environment.WhereCondition are registered under the key whereCondition.
Pretty printer
Pretty printer plugins allow the configuration of presentation of the logic. The instances of class de.uka.iti.pseudo.prettyprint.PrettyPrintPlugin are registered under the key prettyPrinter.
Proof hints
Hints to the proof are given in statement annotations. The instances of interface de.uka.iti.pseudo.auto.strategy.hint.ProofHint are registered under the key proofHint.
Decision procedures
Decision procedures can be used to discharge proof obligations by external solver programs. The instances of interface de.uka.iti.pseudo.auto.DecisionProcedure are registered under the key decisionProcedure.

category.name: Proof hint
category.entry:
Proof hints

Proof hints allow the user to dynamically configure the strategy in use. They are usually added as annotations to assert statements. The branch handling the proof obligation for the asserted formula is then treated differently to the rest of the proof. The exact nature of this different behaviour depends on the configuration of the hints. They can take string arguments.

Proof hint rule

In order to perform a certain rule on a branch, this hint can be used.

Arguments

cut takes one argument which is the name of the rule to be applied.

Example

 assert emptyset <: SetM ; "use the lemma §(rule emptyset_lemma)"

Proof hint expand

In order to expand a recursive definition on a branch, this hint can be used. You can specify how many times a definition is to be unrolled.

Arguments

cut takes one argument which is the name of the rule to be applied.

An optional second argument specifies the number of times the definition is to be unrolled.

Example

If there is a rule which defines the recursive function int f(int): 
 rule f_def
   find f(%x)
   replace 1+f(%x-1)
A hint §(expand f_def) would render a formula f(2) to 1+f(2-1).

A hint §(expand f_def 2) would go a step further and expand to 1 + (1 + f(2-1-1)).

(We left the base case unconsidered here.)

Proof hint pick

This hint allows you to remove formulas from a sequent and to pick only some of them.

Arguments

Takes one or more sequent formula locators which match the regular expression (S|A).[0-9]+. A denoting antecedent and S succedent. The number means the number of the formula on the sequent (0 is first).

Formulas are removed using the hide_left and hide_right rules.

Example

Assume there is a larger complex sequent which looks like
{@code x >= 0, y >= 0, ... |- ...}
and that it helps the verification process to know that {@code x*y >= 0}. The decision procedure, however, is distracted by the remainder of the sequent. Hence we can guide it from within the program by adding 
 {@code assert x*y >= 0 ; "first two imply goal §(pick A0 A1 S0)"}

Proof hint cut

In order to perform a case distinction on a branch, this hint can be used.

Arguments

cut takes one argument which is the formula upon which to perform the cut.

Example

 assert x*x >= 0 ; "examine by sign §(cut 'x >= 0')"

category.name: Where condition
category.entry:
Where conditions

Where conditions are used to formulate constraints von schema instantiations in rule definitions. They describe conditions on the matched terms under which the rule may be applied.

Where conditions can take arguments, but do not have to. For some conditions, marker arguments (schema variables with special names) can be used to specify a particular behaviour of a condition.

Example

The where condition
   where intLiteral %a
in a rule makes the rule only applicable if the schema variable %a is instantiated with an integer literal.

Active where conditions

Where conditions cannot only check the instantiation context but also act and actively modify it.

An active where condition can add new schema instantiations to the context. Existing schema instantiations will not be changed, only new entries added. Please note that active conditions can also fail and not accept an instantiation.

The documentation will point out which parameters are active, and which are passive. Future syntax changes may make the distinction clearer.

Example

The where condition
   freshVar %z, %condition
instantiates %z with a variable of the same type which does not appear (bound or unbound) in the instantiation of %condition.

Where condition toplevel

This condition can be used to ensure that the term which matches the find clause is not within the reach of an update or program modality.

Syntax

The where condition expects no arguments.

Example:

   rule apply_equality 
   assume %a=%b |-
   where toplevel
   find %a
   replace %b
The equality a=5 must not be applied to replace the second a in the expression {a:=7}a=5

See also:

Result:

true if the find clause of the rule matches against a term which is not in the scope of an update or a program modality, false otherwise. Does not fail.

Where condition freshVar

This condition can be used to ensure that a variable does not occur free nor bound in terms.

This is an example of an active condition since it may add variable instantiations. If the first formal parameter is a schema variable, it becomes instantiated with a new variable of the same type which does not occur in the arguments.

The resulting variable is named after the first parameter to the condition, possibly with an added number as suffix.

This condition can also be used to check whether a variable does not appear freely in a term. See second Example

Syntax

The where condition expects a first parameter which can either be a variable or a schema variable. Any number of arbitrary terms may follow.

Example:

   sort S
   function bool p(S, S)
   function bool allP(S)

   rule quant_definition
    find allP(%s1, %s2)
    where freshVar %x, %s2
    replace (\forall %x; p(%x, %s2))
and (to check that a variable does not appear) 
   rule forall_remove
    find (\forall %x; %b)
    where freshVar %x, %b
    replace %b

See also:

noFreeVars

Result:

true if the first argument (or its instantiation) is (or has been chosen by this condition) a variable which does not occur unbound in the remaining arguments. It fails if the first argument is not matched by a variable.

Where condition noFreeVars

This condition can be used to ensure that a term contains no unbound variables.

Syntax

The where condition expects exactly one argument of any type. This can be a schema variable.

Example:

   rule cut_cond
     find cond(%c, %a, %b)
   where
     toplevel
   where
     noFreeVars(%c)
   samegoal "Assume true for {%c}"
     add %c |-
     replace %a
   samegoal "Assume false for {%c}"
     add |- %c

See also:

freshVar

Result:

true if the argument has no free variables, false otherwise, never fails.

Where condition presentInSuccedent

This condition can be used to ensure that a formula is present in the succedent of the sequent.

A formula is considered to be present if it appears toplevel and syntactically equal on the sequent.

If more than one argument is provided, the check will be performed for all arguments. The result will be true only if all arguments pass it.

Syntax

The where condition expects one or more boolean terms as arguments.

Example:

   function int card(set('a))
   
   rule nonneg_cardinality
   find card(%x)
   where not presentInSuccedent card(%x) < 0
   add |- card(%x) < 0

See also:

presentInSequent, presentInAntecedent

Result:

true if the all arguments appear toplevel in the sequent, false otherwise. Does never fail.

Where condition presentInSequent

This condition can be used to ensure that a formula is present either in the antecedent or the succedent of the sequent.

A formula is considered to be present if it appears toplevel and syntactically equal on the sequent.

If more than one argument is provided, the check will be performed for all arguments. The result will be true only if all arguments pass it.

Syntax

The where condition expects one or more boolean terms as arguments.

Example:

   function int f(int)
   
   rule cut_f_zero
   find f(%x)
   where not presentInSequent f(%x)
   samegoal add f(%x) = 0 |-
   samegoal add |- f(%x) = 0

See also:

presentInAntecedent, presentInSuccedent

Result:

true if the all arguments appear toplevel in the sequent, false otherwise. Does never fail.

TODO The where condition UnorderedTerms can be used to check whether two terms are in a certain order. It is used in the normalisation of equations 
 rule equality_order
   find %t = %u |-
   where
     unorderedTerms %t, %u
   replace %u = %t
It signals true iff the order value of %t is greater than the one of %u.

This where condition can be used in rules to indicate that a schema variable should be instantiated interactively.

One parameter

The where condition places a property into the rule application indicating that the schema variable %v of type T is to be interactively instantiated. It is of the form 
   interact(%v) : T
It is then the task of the interaction to process these properties and to amend the schema variable mapping of the rule application.

Two parameters (type mode)

The where condition can also carry a second parameter which must either be true or false (literally). false indicates the usual behaviour while true also allows to instantiate the type of the schema variable (which must be schema type then). This is convenient for type instantiations.

... to be finished ...

Where condition freshTypeVar

This condition can be used to ensure that a type variable does not occur free nor bound in terms.

This is an example of an active condition since it may add schema instantiations. If the first formal parameter has a schema type, this becomes instantiated with a new type variable which does not occur in the arguments.

The resulting variable is named after the first parameter to the condition, possibly with an added number as suffix.

This condition can also be used to check whether a variable does not appear freely in a term. See second Example

Syntax

The where condition expects a first parameter which can either be a variable or a schema variable. Any number of arbitrary terms may follow.

Example:

   to be done
and (to check that a variable does not appear) 
   rule T_all_remove
    find (\T_all %'x; %b)
    where freshTypeVar %'x, %b
    replace %b

See also:

noFreeVars

Result:

true if the first argument (or its instantiation) is (or has been chosen by this condition) a variable which does not occur unbound in the remaining arguments. It fails if the first argument is not matched by a variable.

Where condition distinctAssumeAndFind

This condition can be used to ensure that the find clause does not match the same as any of the assume clauses.

Syntax

The where condition expects no arguments.

Example:

   rule replace_known_left
   assume  %b |-
   find    %b 
   where   toplevel
   where   distinctAssumeAndFind
   replace true
This prevents from replacing an antecedent

See also:

toplevel

Result:

true if the find clauses does not match the same as an assume clause. false if the find clause matches against the same term in a sequent as an assumption.

Where condition intLiteral

This condition can be used to ensure that a term of integer type is a number literal.

Syntax

The where condition expects exactly one argument of type integer. This can be a schema variable.

Example:

   rule add_literal
   find %a + %b
   where intLiteral %a
         intLiteral %b
   replace $$intEval(%a + %b)

See also:

intEval

Result:

true if the argument is a number literal, false otherwise, never fails.

Where condition axiom

This condition can be used to ensure that a term has been defined as an axiom.

In addition to giving the term of an axiom, the property "axiomName" must be set on the rule application

Syntax

The where condition expects one parameter.

Example:

The condition is used in the rule 
   rule `axiom`
   where `axiom` %b
   add %b |-
   tags autoonly
        display "Insert axiom {property axiomName}"
(axiom needs to back-quoted since it is a keyword)

See also:

asAxiom

Result:

true if the argument has been declared as axiom under the specified name. Fails otherwise.

Where condition presentInAntecedent

This condition can be used to ensure that a formula is present either in the antecedent or the succedent of the sequent.

A formula is considered to be present if it appears toplevel and syntactically equal on the sequent.

If more than one argument is provided, the check will be performed for all arguments. The result will be true only if all arguments pass it.

Syntax

The where condition expects one or more boolean terms as arguments.

Example:

   function int card(set('a))
   
   rule positive_cardinality
   find card(%x)
   where not presentInAntecedent card(%x) >= 0
   add card(%x) >= 0 |-

See also:

presentInSequent, presentInSuccedent

Result:

true if the all arguments appear toplevel in the sequent, false otherwise. Does never fail.

category.name: Meta function
category.entry:
Meta function $$skolem

This meta function can be used to create a new skolem symbol. Since ivil does not support free variables (unbound) every skolem symbol is nullary function symbol.

Syntax

The meta function takes one argument of arbitrary type and returns a term of the same type. If applied twice or more often to the same term, it results in the same term. This term is new constant symbol which has not yet occurred in the proof.

Example:

 rule forall_right
   find  |-  (\forall %x; %b)
   replace  $$subst(%x, $$skolem(%x), %b)

See also:

$$subst

Meta function $$subst

This meta function can be used to create a new skolem symbol. Since ivil does not support free variables (unbound) every skolem symbol is nullary function symbol.

Syntax

The meta function takes one argument of arbitrary type and returns a term of the same type. If applied twice or more often to the same term, it results in the same term. This term is new constant symbol which has not yet occurred in the proof.

Example:

 rule forall_right
   find  |-  (\forall %x; %b)
   replace  $$subst(%x, $$skolem(%x), %b)

See also:

$$subst
$$polymorphicSubst
